statements.name: PROC HPF
statements.description: The HPF (High-Performance Forecasting) procedure provides a quick and automatic way to generate forecasts for many time series or transactional data in one step. The procedure can forecast millions of series at a time, with the series organized into separate variables or across BY groups.

arguments.name: BACK=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of observations before the end of the data where the multistep forecasts are to begin. The default is BACK=0.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contain the input data for the procedure to forecast. If the DATA= option is not specified, the most recently created SAS data set is used.

arguments.name: LEAD=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of periods ahead to forecast (forecast lead or horizon). The default is LEAD=12.

arguments.name: MAXERROR=
arguments.description: Limits the number of warning and error messages produced during the execution of the procedure to the specified value. The default is MAXERROR=50. This option is particularly useful in BY-group processing where it can be used to suppress the recurring messages.

arguments.name: NOOUTALL
arguments.description: Specifies that only forecasts are written to the OUT= and OUTFOR= data sets. The NOOUTALL option includes only the final forecast observations in the output data sets, not the one-step forecasts for the data before the forecast period.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the forecasts of the variables that are specified in the subsequent FORECAST statements.

arguments.name: OUTEST=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the model parameter estimates and the associated test statistics and probability values. The OUTEST= data set is particularly useful for evaluating the significance of the model parameters and understanding the model dynamics.

arguments.name: OUTFOR=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the forecast time series components (actual, predicted, lower confidence limit, upper confidence limit, prediction error, and prediction standard error). The OUTFOR= data set is particularly useful for displaying the forecasts in tabular or graphical form.

arguments.name: OUTPROCINFO=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain information in the SAS log, specifically the number of notes, errors, and warnings and the number of series processed, forecasts requested, and forecasts failed.

arguments.name: OUTSEASON=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the seasonal statistics. The statistics are computed for each season as specified by the ID statement INTERVAL= option or the SEASONALITY= option. The OUTSEASON= data set is particularly useful when analyzing transactional data for seasonal variations.

arguments.name: OUTSTAT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the summary statistics and the forecast summation.

arguments.name: OUTSUM=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the summary statistics and the forecast summation.

arguments.name: OUTTREND=
arguments.description: Names the output data set to contain the trend statistics.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Specifies the graphical output desired. By default, the HPF procedure produces no graphical output.
arguments.help: PLOT=ERRORS | ACF | PACF | IACF | WN | MODELS | FORECASTS | MODELFORECASTSONLY | FORECASTSONLY | LEVELS | SEASONS | TRENDS | ALL

arguments.name: ERRORS
arguments.description: Plots prediction error time series graphics.

arguments.name: ACF
arguments.description: Plots prediction error autocorrelation function graphics.

arguments.name: PACF
arguments.description: plots prediction error partial autocorrelation function graphics.

arguments.name: IACF
arguments.description: Plots prediction error inverse autocorrelation function graphics.

arguments.name: WN
arguments.description: Plots white noise graphics.

arguments.name: MODELS
arguments.description: Plots model graphics.

arguments.name: FORECASTS
arguments.description: Plots forecast graphics.

arguments.name: MODELFORECASTSONLY
arguments.description: Plots forecast graphics with confidence limits in the data range.

arguments.name: FORECASTSONLY
arguments.description: Plots the forecast in the forecast horzion only.

arguments.name: LEVELS
arguments.description: Plots smoothed level component graphics.

arguments.name: SEASONS
arguments.description: Plots smoothed seasonal component graphics.

arguments.name: TRENDS
arguments.description: Plots smoothed trend (slope) component graphics.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Is the same as specifying all of the preceding PLOT= options.

arguments.name: PRINT=
arguments.description: Specifies the printed output desired. By default, the HPF procedure produces no printed output.
arguments.help: PRINT=ESTIMATES | FORECASTS | PERFORMANCE | PERFORMANCESUMMARY | PERFORMANCEOVERALL | SEASONS | STATISTICS | STATES | SUMMARY | TRENDS | ALL

arguments.name: ESTIMATES
arguments.description: Prints the results of parameter estimation (OUTEST= data set).

arguments.name: FORECASTS
arguments.description: Prints the forecasts (OUTFOR= data set).

arguments.name: PERFORMANCE
arguments.description: Prints the performance statistics for each forecast.

arguments.name: PERFORMANCESUMMARY
arguments.description: Prints the performance summary for each BY group.

arguments.name: PERFORMANCEOVERALL
arguments.description: Prints the performance summary for all of the BY groups.

arguments.name: SEASONS
arguments.description: Prints the seasonal statistics (OUTSEASON= data set).

arguments.name: STATISTICS
arguments.description: Prints the statistics of fit (OUTSTAT= data set).

arguments.name: STATES
arguments.description: Prints the backcast, initial, and final states.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Prints the summary statistics for the accumulated time series (OUTSUM= data set).

arguments.name: TRENDS
arguments.description: Prints the trend statistics (OUTTREND= data set).

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Is the same as PRINT=(ESTIMATES FORECASTS STATISTICS SUMMARY).

arguments.name: PRINTDETAILS
arguments.description: Specifies that output requested with the PRINT= option be printed in greater detail.

arguments.name: SEASONALITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the seasonal cycle.

arguments.name: SORTNAMES
arguments.description: Specifies that the variables specified in the FORECAST statements be processed in sorted order.

arguments.name: STARTSUM=
arguments.description: Specifies the starting forecast lead (or horizon) for which to begin summation of the forecasts specified by the LEAD= option.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC HPF to obtain separate analyses for groups of observations defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: FORECAST
statements.description: The FORECAST statement lists the numeric variables in the DATA= data set whose accumulated values represent time series to be modeled and forecast. The options specify which forecast model is to be used or how the forecast model is selected from several possible candidate models.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are to be accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level to use in computing the confidence limits of the forecast.

arguments.name: CRITERION=
arguments.description: Specifies the model selection criterion (statistic of fit) to be used to select from several candidate models.

arguments.name: HOLDOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the holdout sample to be used for model selection. The holdout sample is a subset of actual time series that end at the last nonmissing observation.

arguments.name: HOLDOUTPCT=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the holdout sample as a percentage of the length of the time series.

arguments.name: INTERMITTENT=
arguments.description: Specifies a number greater than one which is used to determine whether or not a time series is intermittent.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Specifies that the median forecast values are to be estimated. Forecasts can be based on the mean or median. By default the mean value is provided.

arguments.name: MODEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the forecasting model to be used to forecast the actual time series.
arguments.help: MODEL=NONE | SIMPLE | DOUBLE | LINEAR | DAMPTREND | ADDSEASONAL | MULTSEASONAL | WINTERS | ADDWINTERS | BEST | BESTN | BESTS | IDM | BESTALL*model-name*

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No forecast

arguments.name: SIMPLE
arguments.description: Simple (single) exponential smoothing

arguments.name: DOUBLE
arguments.description: Double (Brown) exponential smoothing

arguments.name: LINEAR
arguments.description: Linear (Holt) exponential smoothing

arguments.name: DAMPTREND
arguments.description: Damped trend exponential smoothing

arguments.name: ADDSEASONAL
arguments.description: Additive seasonal exponential smoothing

arguments.name: MULTSEASONAL
arguments.description: Multiplicative seasonal exponential smoothing

arguments.name: WINTERS
arguments.description: Winters multiplicative Method

arguments.name: ADDWINTERS
arguments.description: Winters additive Method

arguments.name: BEST
arguments.description: Best candidate smoothing model (SIMPLE, DOUBLE, LINEAR, DAMPTREND, ADDSEASONAL, WINTERS, ADDWINTERS)

arguments.name: BESTN
arguments.description: Best candidate nonseasonal smoothing model (SIMPLE, DOUBLE, LINEAR, DAMPTREND)

arguments.name: BESTS
arguments.description: Best candidate seasonal smoothing model (ADDSEASONAL, WINTERS, ADDWINTERS)

arguments.name: IDM
arguments.description: Intermittent demand model such as Croston’s method or average demand model.

arguments.name: BESTALL
arguments.description: Best candidate model (IDM, BEST)

arguments.name: NBACKCAST=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of observations used to initialize the backcast states.

arguments.name: REPLACEBACK
arguments.description: Specifies that actual values excluded by the BACK= option be replaced with one-step-ahead forecasts in the OUT= data set.

arguments.name: REPLACEMISSING
arguments.description: Specifies that embedded missing actual values be replaced with one-step-ahead forecasts in the OUT= data set.

arguments.name: SEASONTEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the options related to the seasonality test. This option is used with the MODEL=BEST and MODEL=BESTALL options.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No test

arguments.name: (SIGLEVEL=)
arguments.description: Significance probability value

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are to be assigned in the accumulated time series for variables listed in the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: TRANSFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the actual time series.
arguments.help: TRANSFORM=NONE | LOG | SQRT | LOGISTIC | BOXCOX | AUTO*option*

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No transformation is applied. This option is the default.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Logarithmic transformation

arguments.name: SQRT
arguments.description: Square-root transformation

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: Logistic transformation

arguments.name: BOXCOX
arguments.description: Box-Cox transformation with parameter number where number is between –5 and 5

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: Automatically choose between NONE and LOG based on model selection criteria

arguments.name: USE=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the actual time series.

arguments.name: PREDICT
arguments.description: The predicted values are appended to the actual values. This option is the default.

arguments.name: LOWER
arguments.description: The lower confidence limit values are appended to the actual values.

arguments.name: UPPER
arguments.description: The upper confidence limit values are appended to the actual values.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies the time series transformation to be applied to the actual time series.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies observations in the input and output data sets. The ID variable’s values are assumed to be SAS date, time, or datetime values.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are to be accumulated within each time period for the variables listed in the FORECAST statement.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATENONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: Controls the alignment of SAS dates used to identify output observations.

arguments.name: BEGINNING
arguments.description: Beginning

arguments.name: MIDDLE
arguments.description: Middle

arguments.name: ENDING
arguments.description: End

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the end of the data.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS format for the time ID values.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the frequency of the input time series.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that the time ID values not be in sorted order.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are to be assigned in the accumulated time series.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date, datetime, or time value that represents the beginning of the data.

arguments.name: ZEROMISS=
arguments.description: Specifies how missing values (either actual or accumulated) are to be assigned in the accumulated time series.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Beginning and/or ending zeros unchanged. This is the default.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Beginning zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Ending zeros are set to missing.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Both beginning and ending zeros are set to missing.

statements.name: IDM
statements.description: The IDM statement is used to specify an intermittent demand model.

arguments.name: AVERAGE=
arguments.description: Specifies the smoothing model used to forecast the demand average component.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: Specifies the base value of the time series used to determine the demand series components.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: The base value is automatically determined by the time series median, minimum and maximum values, and the INTERMITTENT= option value of the FORECAST statement.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the smoothing model used to forecast the demand interval component.

arguments.name: SIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the smoothing model used to forecast the demand size component.
